pull.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to use your hands to make something or someone move towards you or in the direction that your hands are moving
pull.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: She pulled open the door and hurried inside.
He pulled her down into her seat.
pull somebody/something into/away from/over etc something
pull.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to use force to take something from the place where it is fixed or held
pull.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: She has to have two teeth pulled.
Vicky had pulled the arm off her doll.
pull.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to be attached to something or hold something and make it move behind you in the direction you are going
pull.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to take something out of a bag, pocket etc with your hand
pull a gun/knife (on somebody) (=take one out, ready to use it)
pull.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: He pulled out his wallet and said ‘let me pay’.
Ben pulled a pen from his pocket.
pull.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: to put on or take off a piece of clothing, usually quickly
pull.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: He pulled off his damp shirt.
pull.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to move your body or part of your body away from someone or something
pull.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: She tried to pull her hand free, but it was held fast.
She struggled fiercely, trying to pull her arm out of his grasp.
pull.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: to hold onto something and use your strength to move your body towards it
pull.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: Benny pulled himself up from the floor with difficulty.
pull.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: to injure one of your muscles by stretching it too much during physical activity
pull.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: Paul pulled a muscle trying to lift the freezer.
pull.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: to succeed in doing something illegal or dishonest or in playing a trick on someone
pull.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: The gang have pulled another bank robbery.
He was trying to pull a fast one (=deceive you) when he told you he’d paid.
Don’t you ever pull a stunt like that again!
pull.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: to move a control such as a switch, lever, or trigger towards you to make a piece of equipment work
pull.translation[0].definitions[9].examp: She raised the gun, and pulled the trigger.
pull.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: if an event, performer etc pulls crowds or a politician pulls a lot of votes, a lot of people come to see them or vote for them
pull.translation[0].definitions[10].exam: Muhammad Ali can still pull the crowds.
pull.translation[0].definitions[11].defi: to attract or influence someone or their thoughts or feelings
pull.translation[0].definitions[11].exam: The city’s reputation for a clean environment has pulled new residents from other states.
pull.translation[0].definitions[12].defi: to attract someone in order to have sex with them or spend the evening with them
pull.translation[0].definitions[12].exam: He knew he could pull any girl he wanted.
pull.translation[0].definitions[13].defi: to stop a planned event from taking place
pull.translation[0].definitions[14].defi: to drive a vehicle somewhere and stop, or to make a vehicle gradually slow down and stop
pull.translation[0].definitions[14].exam: The bus pulled to a halt.
She pulled the car into a side street.
pull.translation[0].definitions[15].defi: if a car pulls to the left or right as you are driving, it moves in that direction because of a problem with its machinery
pull.translation[0].definitions[16].defi: to get beer out of a barrel by pulling a handle
pull.translation[0].definitions[16].exam: The barman laughed and began to pull a couple of pints.
pull.translation[0].definitions[17].defi: to hit the ball in cricket, golf, or baseball so that it does not go straight but moves to one side
pull.translation[0].definitions[18].defi: to make a boat move by using oars
pull.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: pull
to make something or someone move in the direction that your hands are moving
He pulled her towards him and kissed her.
Sam was pulling on his socks.
tug
to pull something suddenly with a short quick movement, often to get someone’s attention
‘Look, ’ he said, tugging at his brother’s sleeve.
I tugged at the drawer but it wouldn’t open.
drag
to pull something along the ground, especially because it is heavy
If we can’t lift the piano, we’ll have to drag it.
haul
to pull something big and heavy using a lot of effort, especially upwards and using a rope
They hauled their boats further up the beach.
fishermen hauling in their nets
heave
to pull or lift something very heavy, especially with one movement
He heaved the sack of sand onto his shoulder.
draw
to pull something or someone gently in a particular direction
Lisa reached for his hand but he drew it away.
pull
to be attached to a vehicle or piece of machinery and make it move behind you in the direction you are going
Ten dogs were pulling a sledge over the ice.
a tractor pulling a plough
tow
to pull a vehicle behind – used about a vehicle, a boat, or a horse pulling something using a rope or chain
The car in front of us was towing a caravan.
Horses were used to tow the boats along the canals.
draw
to pull a vehicle such as a carriage – used especially about horses doing this
a carriage drawn by four horses
a horse-drawn cart
pull.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: an act of using force to move something towards you or in the same direction that you are moving
pull.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: He gave her a sharp pull forward.
pull.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: a strong physical force that makes things move in a particular direction
pull.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: the gravitational pull of the Moon
pull.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: the ability to attract someone or have a powerful effect on them
pull.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: After about a year I gave in to the pull of fatherhood.
pull.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: special influence or power over other people
pull.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: His family’s name gives him a lot of pull in this town.
pull.translation[1].definitions[4].defin: a difficult climb up a steep road
pull.translation[1].definitions[4].examp: It was a long pull up the hill.
pull.translation[1].definitions[5].defin: an injury to one of your muscles, caused by stretching it too much during exercise
pull.translation[1].definitions[6].defin: an act of taking the smoke from a cigarette, pipe etc into your lungs or of taking a long drink of something
pull.translation[1].definitions[6].examp: She took a long pull on her cigarette.
pull.translation[1].definitions[7].defin: a rope or handle that you use to pull something
pull.translation[1].definitions[7].examp: He popped the ring pull on another can of lager.
pull.translation[1].definitions[8].defin: a way of hitting the ball in cricket, golf, or baseball so that it does not go straight, but moves to one side
